verbs.description: concentre (third-person singular simple present concentres, present participle concentring, simple past and past participle concentred)

entries.meaning: (British spelling, dated, intransitive) To come together at a common centre.
examples: As from each angle of the Vault
Wherein thou lyest, a line is brought
So vnto thee, from euery part,
See how our loues doe runne by line,
And dead, concenter in thy Shrine.
Are we not sufficiently Brutes, to call that work brutish which begets us?  […]  All Opinions concenter in this  […]

entries.meaning: (British spelling, dated, transitive) To bring together at a common centre.
examples: For one so rarely tun’d to fit all parts;
For one to whom espous’d are all the Arts;
Long have I sought for: but co’d never see
Them all concenter’d in one man, but Thee.
At Princess Paryli’s Ball two young men of singular elegance were observed by Diana, little though she concentered her attention on any figures of the groups.

entries.meaning: (transitive, British spelling, dated) To condense, to concentrate.
examples: As new discoveries were made incidental difficulties connected with the filling of shells occupied the concentered study of the manufacturers.
